note.p: Richard Bennett Hubbard, Jr., was a Confederate soldier, politician, and diplomat, who served as governor of Texas during the late Reconstruction era.

Born on November 1, 1832, in Walton County, Georgia, Hubbard graduated from Mercer Institute with a degree in literature in 1851. A gifted speaker and scholar, he then attended lectures at the University of Virginia and graduated with a law degree from Harvard in 1853. He moved to Texas with his parents after graduation and became active in Democratic Party politics. He was appointed U.S. attorney for the western district of Texas in 1857 and two years later won a seat in the Texas legislature.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Hubbard initially sought political office in the new Confederacy. However, after losing an election to the Confederate Congress, he helped raise the Fifth Texas Infantry Battalion and became its commander. In March 1862, the battalion became part of the Twenty-second Texas Infantry Regiment, with Hubbard as its major. He was quickly promoted to lieutenant colonel in May 1862, and then colonel in June 1862. Hubbard led the regiment during campaigns in the Trans-Mississippi Department (the area west of the Mississippi River) and saw combat in Arkansas and Louisiana.

After the Civil War, Hubbard practiced law, sold real estate, and became active in railroad ventures. The activities helped him rebuild his wealth and he reentered politics in the early 1870s. He served as a presidential elector in 1872 in support of Democratic candidate Horace Greeley. The following year, Hubbard was elected lieutenant governor of Texas. He won reelection in 1876, and then stepped into the governor’s office when Richard Coke resigned that position to take a seat in the U.S. Senate.

As governor, Hubbard helped reduce Texas’ debt, promoted public education, and combatting land fraud. He served only one term, but remained active in Democratic politics after leaving state office. His support of Grover Cleveland’s nomination to the presidency resulted in an appointment as Minister to Japan in 1885. Hubbard proved a capable diplomat who advanced U.S.-Japanese relations during a key transition period in that developing Asian country. After returning to the United States in 1889, he published a book of his experiences as a diplomat, entitled The United States in the Far East.

Hubbard died on July 12, 1901. He was married twice, first to Eliza Hudson, who died in 1868. He then married Olivia Roberts in 1869. She passed away in 1887. Hubbard had at least nine children. He is buried in Oakwood Cemetery in Tyler, Texas.
Richard Bennett Hubbard belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Winston County, Louisville was founded as early as 1836 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
The Republic of Texas was established on March 2, 1836. Admitted as the 28th state, Texas achieved statehood December 29, 1845. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "The crime of intentionally killing a person." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"An amount of money set for a person accused of a crime to be released from a law enforcement facility until trial." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Criminal Procedures--Charges and Specifications (Civil and Criminal)

gloss.p: "To make a formal statement saying that someone is accused of a crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Executive department of the State of Texas consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, agriculture commissioner, state comptroller of accounts, land commissioner, education board, Texas Railroad Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Stone Collection. Letter from M. A. Coleman to Mississippi Governor John M. Stone, reporting arrest of W. A. Parkes under requisition from Texas.

div.fw: Letter from M. A. Coleman to Mississippi Governor John M. Stone; April 4, 1877
div.p: Bond of G. Y. Mitts April 4th" at 12 o clock M one W. A. Parks—Charged with the Crime of murdering Geo. Perkins on the 24th" day of Decmbr A D 1876 And Arrested by Said Mitts in the State of Texas under requisition of the Gov. of Said State of Texas—on 23d" day of March 1877—
div.note: Penmanship is quite difficult to read, so AI assistance would be very valuable for the successful drafting of this page.
